data.title: The Finest in New England
data.text: As A Funeral Director for almost a half century, I have seen it all, been in most cemeteries and have experienced side by side with families choosing The Newton Cemetery for their final resting place. I can only say that my families graves are at The Newton Cemetery.

data.title: Cure your nature deficit disorder here
data.text: Nearby our house and a lovely walk any time of the year. They give occasional nature walks with a knowledgeable guide. Fall color, quiet winter walks, spectacular spring blooming trees and flowers and good bird watching right before that. Good place to practice your walking meditation.

data.title: Not your usual cemetery!
data.text: When I was looking for an urn plot a couple of years ago, I took a look at Newton Cemetery. What I found was a serene/easy on the eye and lovely space with foliage and flowers that were quite extraordinary. The gentleman who showed me the various sections was "up" on trees so I asked him how he ended up working at a cemetery. He said he studied horticulture and previously had managed a golf course! It actually made sense. If you happen to be in the Area and are in need of a quiet and contemplative place for a walk, this is worth stopping by. It's not as dramatic as Forest Hills or Mt Auburn but, in its own right, offers something to those of us needing a few minutes off the beaten path.

data.title: A beautaiful spring, summer or fall walk - in the traditiaon of New ENgland's Transcentalists
data.text: in the early 21st century many sensitive people's absolute last desire is to walk in a cemetery.   The people who layed out this cemetery in the middle of the 19th century saw a cemetery which had beautiful bushes, blooming trees, flowers, along with benches to sit on, and poetry near some of the tombs and gravestones was viewed quite differently.   The beauty of the growths, reminded strollers of the life of those buried there, and of the world.   This Cemetery was a place to commune with nature.   It really depends on your own interpretation.  For many of us, it is the power of life, and the beauty of the plantings which restores our souls.    Bob Krim

data.title: Another beautiful spot for an easy walk.
data.text: This is another example of a nineteenth century garden cemetery, beautifully maintained and lovely to walk through. Plenty of people use it as part of their daily walk regimen as it is easy to get to but also quiet and secluded. It has plenty of shade trees and planted flower beds.

data.title: Perfect for a peaceful walk if you are nearby
data.text: This is in my town and I have walked in it for years.  Its beautifully planted, much more like an arboretum than the traditional cemetery.  Rolling hills and several ponds. Our children loved it when they were small because of the geese, ducks, and turtles. Its not that big so don't think I would make a special trip like I would for Mount Auburn, but if you're nearby and looking for a beautiful and peaceful place to walk, I highly recommend it.

data.title: beautiful grounds and fascinating memorials
data.text: There are great variety of plantings, trees,shrubbery, flowers, a lake and fountains.  I have taken  a tour with an arborist guide  of the trees and their histories.  This is a jewel.

data.title: A serene and beautiful place in the city
data.text: This is an exceptionally lovely garden cemetery, located in the heart of Newton (a city of more than 80,000 not far from Boston).  Like the better-know Mt. Auburn Cemetery in nearby Cambridge, the Newton Cemetery has a gorgeous and varied landscape with ponds, a huge variety of trees, and constantly-changing plantings of seasonal flowers.  This is a non-denominational cemetery, and one of the most intriguing aspects is examining the gravestones and monuments, reflecting the ethnic diversity of the Newton community.   I walk with friends in the cemetery nearly every week, as do many other local residents.  It is a joy to have this space available to the community.

data.title: The old section rivals Mount Auburn but way smaller!
data.text: The old section of this cemetery is as good an example of landscape architecture as can be found in suburban Boston. Park, walk, absorb the peaceful tranquility of what an eternal resting place could be.   Newton Cemetery is a wonderful place to visit in every season, especially Spring-in-bloom and then to relish in the fall colors.  Specimen trees, lovely plantings, unusual headstones and quiet ponds make this place worthy of a one hour stroll four times a year.  It also connects to the quaint Olmstead designed Newton City Hall frontage on Walnut Street and Bullough's Pond next to Commonwealth Avenue so add an extra hour to your first visit and experience all three. .

data.title: A walk into serenity
data.text:
The Newton Cemetery has two faces:
1. A serene location honoring those who have passed, but are not forgotten.
2. A place for reflection, meditation, and mindfulness.
The Newton Cemetery serves both the living, and those buried at this beautifully manicured, and maintained location. It is a welcoming place for those of all faiths, and for every reason one has to visit.

data.title: Great Walking
data.text: A beautiful place to walk. Nice duck pond to bring the kids to feed the ducks. Nice veterans's lot across from the duck pond.

data.title: Gorgeous rural cemetery.
data.text: Choose a beautiful day and stroll for a couple of hours in this beautiful park-like setting.  Print out a list of the many notables enjoying eternal rest in one of this country's earliest rural cemeteries.

data.title: If Garden Cemeteries Are Your Thing…..
data.text: A lovely place to walk (though not quite like Mt Auburn in Cambridge. Peaceful. Beautiful grounds. Birds.  Get away from it all….

data.title: Not a lot of famous people buried here.
data.text: I don't know why a cemetery would be a tourist attraction unless it many famous people are buried there.  Such is the case at Cambridge's Mt. Vernon Cemetery - but not here.  Sure, Dom DiMaggio is buried on the lawn.  Louis Liggett, who founded the old Liggett's Pharmacy Chain is buried there somewhere.  And so are some former governors of the Commonwealth - but no recent ones.  The only contemporary actor here is Arnold Stang, who has appeared in over 100 tv shows and movies up to  the mid-1990s - all as a character actor in small roles.   The grounds are pretty as many cemeteries are, but not a real tourist destination for sure.

owner_response.author: NewtonCemetery, General Manager at Newton Cemetery, responded to this review
owner_response.text: Cemeteries are beautiful, peaceful and interesting places to visit for many reasons, even if they may not be considered a tourist attraction.  As pointed out, Newton Cemetery does have a number of notables.  An on-line Notables tour is available at the Newton Cemetery website (https://www.newcemcorp.org/explore/online-tours). Many names of those interred here are notable on a local level. Newton residents would certainly recognize them and find their stories fascinating – Farlow, F.A. Day, Bigelow, Underwood, Mason and Rice to name a few. Newton Cemetery is also an accredited Arboretum, one of only a handful in the state of Massachusetts. An on-line Tree Tour is available and tree, history and bird walks are held on the grounds throughout the year for those who want to learn more about the different features of Newton Cemetery.
